Knowledge Point: As these examples show, the subject can be either omitted \REF{ex:10.1} or expressed (\ref{ex:10.2}–\ref{ex:10.5}). If expressed, it is a 2\textsuperscript{nd} person pronoun placed after the verb. Unlike other subject pronouns, it is not preceded by the proper article\is{a (proper article)} a (\sectref{sec:5.13.2.1}).
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Ka} \textbf{e\ꞌa} ki haho \textbf{ka} \textbf{to\ꞌo} mai hai vai mā\ꞌaku mo unu. | \gls IMP go_out to outside IMP take hither INS water BEN.1SG.A for drink | \glt ‘Go outside and bring water for me to drink.’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Ka} \textbf{uru} mai kōrua ki roto. | \gls IMP enter hither 2PL to inside | \glt ‘Come in (said to two people).’
Content 3: \gll \textbf{E} \textbf{hāpa\ꞌo} kōrua i a Puakiva. | \gls EXH care_for 2PL ACC PROP Puakiva | \glt ‘Take care of Puakiva.’

Knowledge Point: As discussed in \sectref{sec:8.4.1}, the direct object has the accusative marker i when the subject is expressed (as in \ref{ex:10.5}); when the subject is not expressed, the accusative marker\is{i (accusative marker)} is omitted.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{E} \textbf{hāpa\ꞌo} kōrua i a Puakiva. | \gls EXH care_for 2PL ACC PROP Puakiva | \glt ‘Take care of Puakiva.’

Knowledge Point: The imperative\is{Imperative} can be used with any verb. It is rarely used with adjectives, but this may have pragmatic rather than syntactic reasons: there are simply not many situations in which it is appropriate to order someone to have a certain property. For an example of an imperative-marked adjective, see \REF{ex:3.90} on p.~\pageref{ex:3.90}.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Ka} \textbf{koa} mai \ꞌāpī \ꞌe mai nehenehe a koe. | \gls IMP happy while new and while beautiful PROP 2SG | \glt ‘Be happy as long as you are young and beautiful.’

Knowledge Point: As \REF{ex:10.14} shows, ki is also used to mark proposals in question form.
Content 1: \gll ¿Ki aŋa te \ꞌāriŋa ora mo to mātou korohu\ꞌa? | \gls ~HORT make ART face live for ART:of 1PL.EXCL old_man | \glt ‘Shall we make a memento (lit. living face) for our father?’

Knowledge Point: \textit{{\ꞌ}Ō}\is{o (asseverative)@{\ꞌ}ō (asseverative)} in \REF{ex:10.18} and \REF{ex:10.20} indicates counterexpectation\is{Counterexpectation} (\sectref{sec:4.5.4.5}); it is used in rhetorical questions to which a negative answer is expected, or in negative rhetorical questions to which a positive answer is expected.
Content 1: \gll ¿\ꞌIna \ꞌō koe he oho ki te hāpī? | \gls ~NEG really 2SG NTR go to ART learn | \glt ‘Don’t you go to school?’
Content 2: \gll ¿Hai kai piropiro \ꞌō ana va\ꞌai mai ki a māua? | \gls ~INS food rotten:RED really IRR give hither to PROP 1DU.EXCL | \glt ‘Are you giving us rotten food?’

Knowledge Point: Hō\is{ho (dubitative)@hō (dubitative)} in \REF{ex:10.19} indicates doubt (\sectref{sec:4.5.4.6}).
Content 1: \gll ¿E tano rō hō te me\ꞌe mana\ꞌu era e Tuki mo aŋa? | \gls ~IPFV correct EMPH DUB ART thing think DIST AG Tuki for do | \glt ‘Is it correct what Tuki plans to do?’

Knowledge Point: When a constituent within the clause is questioned, it is in focus\is{Focus} position: it is fronted as in \REF{ex:10.20}.
Content 1: \gll ¿Hai kai piropiro \ꞌō ana va\ꞌai mai ki a māua? | \gls ~INS food rotten:RED really IRR give hither to PROP 1DU.EXCL | \glt ‘Are you giving us rotten food?’

Knowledge Point: \is{hoki (polar questions)|(}Polar questions may be marked with hoki (glossed \textsc{pq} = polar question), which is placed at the start of the sentence. Hoki is less common in modern Rapa Nui than in older texts, but it does occur. It is used especially when the speaker expects a certain answer to the question, whether affirmative as in (\ref{ex:10.21}–\ref{ex:10.22}) or negative as in (\ref{ex:10.23}–\ref{ex:10.24}). For example, in \REF{ex:10.22} the context makes clear that the speaker assumes that the hearer has indeed heard the dream; on the other hand, in \REF{ex:10.23}, the speaker does not believe that the hearer has ever seen a devil.
Content 1: \gll ¿Hoki e ai rō \ꞌā te famiria? | \gls ~~PQ IPFV exist EMPH CONT ART family | \glt ‘You have a family (don’t you)?’
Content 2: \gll ¿Hoki ko ŋaro\ꞌa \ꞌā e koe te vārua nei \ꞌa Hina? | \gls ~~PQ PRF perceive CONT AG 2SG ART spirit PROX of.A Hina | \glt ‘Did you hear Hina’s dream?’
Content 3: \gll ¿Hoki ko tike\ꞌa \ꞌā e koe te tātane ra\ꞌe? | \gls ~~PQ PRF see CONT AG 2SG ART devil first | \glt ‘Have you ever seen a devil?’
Content 4: \gll ¿Hoki e ketu rō koe i te hare o te taŋata ki raro? | \gls ~~PQ IPFV raise EMPH 2SG ACC ART house of ART man to below | \glt ‘(one wind to another:) Could you destroy someone’s house (lit. raise down a house of a man)?!’
Content 5: \gll ¿Hoki ko ŋaro\ꞌa \ꞌā e koe te vārua nei \ꞌa Hina? | \gls ~~PQ PRF perceive CONT AG 2SG ART spirit PROX of.A Hina | \glt ‘Did you hear Hina’s dream?’
Content 6: \gll ¿Hoki ko tike\ꞌa \ꞌā e koe te tātane ra\ꞌe? | \gls ~~PQ PRF see CONT AG 2SG ART devil first | \glt ‘Have you ever seen a devil?’

Knowledge Point: When a question contains a negation, it depends on the underlying presupposition which answering strategy (‘yes’ or ‘no’) is appropriate. In the following examples, the person asking the question presupposes that the underlying proposition is true; in \REF{ex:10.25} for example, the speaker expects that the person pointed out is indeed Vivika. The positive reply ‘yes’ confirms this expectation. In \REF{ex:10.26}, the asker expects the addressee to want to have him as father; negative response ‘no’ refutes this expectation.
Content 1: \gll —¿Ta\ꞌe ko Vivika? —\ꞌĒē. Ko ia. | \gls ~~~~~CONNEG PROM Vivika ~~~yes PROM 3SG | \glt ‘—Isn’t that Vivika? —Yes, it’s her.’
Content 2: \gll —¿Kai haŋa \ꞌō koe ko au \ꞌā tō\ꞌou matu\ꞌa? —\ꞌIna, tō\ꞌoku mau \ꞌā. | \gls ~~~~~NEG.PFV want really 2SG PROM 1SG IDENT POSS.2SG.O parent ~~~NEG~ POSS.1SG.O really IDENT | \glt ‘—Don’t you want me to be your father? —No, I want my own (father).’

Knowledge Point: When ai is any core argument (regardless of its semantic role), a cleft\is{Cleft} construction can be used (\sectref{sec:9.2.6}).\footnote{\label{fn:487}\citet{PotsdamPolinsky2011} distinguish three questioning strategies in Polynesian: displacement (= preposing the Wh-constituent), clefts, and pseudo-clefts (=clefts in which the relative clause\is{Clause!relative} has a head noun; in Rapa Nui, this is the only cleft\is{Cleft} strategy possible, see sec. \sectref{sec:9.2.6} and \sectref{sec:8.6.2.1}). They tentatively analyse Rapa Nui as using the displacement strategy, but admit that data are scarce. One example is given of a construction as in \REF{ex:10.36}, as well as a number of oblique examples (which indeed have a displacement structure), and one example of he aha in the sense of ‘why’ (which is also an oblique with displacement). However, in Rapa Nui texts, pseudo-clefts abound in questions, both with ai ‘who’ (such as in (\ref{ex:10.33}–\ref{ex:10.35})) and with aha ‘what’ (such as \REF{ex:10.44} in the next section).} In this construction, ko ai is a nominal predicate, followed by a subject containing a relative clause\is{Clause!relative}. The subject noun is usually the generic \is{mee ‘thing’@me{\ꞌ}e ‘thing’}\textit{me{\ꞌ}e}, though other nouns are also used. A few examples:
Content 1: \gll ¿Ko ai i mate? | \gls ~PROM who PFV die | \glt ‘Who died?’
Content 2: \gll ¿Ko ai te me\ꞌe ŋau era i te kiko \ꞌai? | \gls ~PROM who ART thing bite DIST ACC ART meat there | \glt ‘Who is the one biting the meat there?’
Content 3: \gll ¿Ko ai te me\ꞌe ena e kōrua ka haka tere ena? | \gls ~PROM who ART thing MED AG 2PL CNTG CAUS run MED | \glt ‘(If everybody wants to govern the island,) whom will you govern?’
Content 4: \gll ¿He aha te me\ꞌe i topa ki a koro? | \gls ~PRED who ART thing PFV happen to PROP Dad | \glt ‘What happened to Dad?’

Knowledge Point: When ai questions an \textsc{oblique} constituent, this constituent is simply fronted.\footnote{\label{fn:488}As (\ref{ex:10.39}–\ref{ex:10.40}) show, if the clause also has a subject, it is usually preverbal. This is usual after most preverbal constituents (\sectref{sec:8.6.1.1}).}
Content 1: \gll ¿\textbf{Ki} \textbf{a} \textbf{ai} a Omoaŋa i māhani ai \ꞌi \ꞌŌroŋo? | \gls ~to PROP who PROP Omoanga PFV accustomed PVP at Orongo | \glt ‘Who did Omoanga get to know in Orongo?’
Content 2: \gll ¿\textbf{\ꞌI} \textbf{muri} \textbf{i} \textbf{a} \textbf{ai} a Eva ka noho era \ꞌi a Tire? | \gls ~at near at PROP who PROP Eva CNTG stay DIST at PROP Chile | \glt ‘With whom would Eva stay in Chile?’

Knowledge Point: More commonly, the O argument is questioned. As in all object relative clauses\is{Clause!relative} (\sectref{sec:11.4.2}), the subject is either marked with e as in \REF{ex:10.45}, or the possessive-relative\is{Clause!possessive-relative} construction is used (\sectref{sec:11.4.4}) as in \REF{ex:10.46}.
Content 1: \gll ¿He aha te me\ꞌe i kī atu e Kihi? | \gls ~PRED what ART thing PFV say away AG Kihi | \glt ‘What did Kihi say?’
Content 2: \gll ¿He aha te kōrua me\ꞌe i aŋa i \ꞌApina? | \gls ~PRED what ART 2PL thing PFV do at Apina | \glt ‘What did you do in Apina?’

Knowledge Point: He aha is also used in the sense ‘why’. In this case, it is an oblique, which is part of a simple verbal clause with preverbal subject: he aha S V. The structure of the sentence is thus different from he aha as subject or object, which have a cleft structure he aha [NP Rel]; compare \REF{ex:10.51} with (\ref{ex:10.45}–\ref{ex:10.46}) above:
Content 1: \gll ¿He aha koe e taŋi ena? | \gls ~PRED what 2SG IPFV cry MED | \glt ‘Why are you crying?’
Content 2: \gll ¿He aha te me\ꞌe i kī atu e Kihi? | \gls ~PRED what ART thing PFV say away AG Kihi | \glt ‘What did Kihi say?’
Content 3: \gll ¿He aha te kōrua me\ꞌe i aŋa i \ꞌApina? | \gls ~PRED what ART 2PL thing PFV do at Apina | \glt ‘What did you do in Apina?’

Knowledge Point: \subparagraph{Location} When preceded by a locative preposition (\textit{{\ꞌ}i} ‘at’ ki ‘to’, mai ‘from’, a ‘by, towards’) or o ‘of’, hē has a locative sense ‘where’. As the examples show, hē may be the predicate of a verbless clause as in (\ref{ex:10.54}–\ref{ex:10.55}), or an oblique in a verbal clause as in (\ref{ex:10.56}–\ref{ex:10.58}). In verbal clauses, the subject is usually preverbal.
Content 1: \gll ¿\ꞌI hē koe \ꞌi te ŋā tiempo nei \ꞌī a\ꞌa? | \gls ~at CQ 2SG at ART PL time PROX IMM DEIC | \glt ‘Where were you in these times?’
Content 2: \gll ¿O hē te taŋata era? | \gls ~of CQ ART man DIST | \glt ‘Where is that man from?’
Content 3: \gll ¿\ꞌI hē a koe e noho ena? | \gls ~at CQ PROP 2SG IPFV stay MED | \glt ‘Where do you live?’
Content 4: \gll ¿Ki hē kōrua ko te poki i iri mai ena? | \gls ~to CQ 2PL PROM ART child PFV ascend hither MED | \glt ‘Where did you and the child go up to?’

Knowledge Point: In nominal clauses\is{Clause!nominal}, hē is also used without a preceding preposition. Its sense is similar to \textit{{\ꞌ}i hē} ‘where’, but it is only used to ask about things that are situationally close; often, the addressee is directly involved. Compare (\ref{ex:10.59}–\ref{ex:10.60}) with \REF{ex:10.54} and \REF{ex:10.56} above:
Content 1: \gll ¿Hē koe, e vovo ē? | \gls ~CQ 2SG VOC dear_girl VOC | \glt ‘Where are you, my girl?’
Content 2: \gll ¿Hē te kona mamae atu? | \gls ~CQ ART place pain away | \glt ‘Where is the place (=body part) that hurts?’
Content 3: \gll ¿\ꞌI hē koe \ꞌi te ŋā tiempo nei \ꞌī a\ꞌa? | \gls ~at CQ 2SG at ART PL time PROX IMM DEIC | \glt ‘Where were you in these times?’
Content 4: \gll ¿\ꞌI hē a koe e noho ena? | \gls ~at CQ PROP 2SG IPFV stay MED | \glt ‘Where do you live?’

Knowledge Point: \subparagraph{Time} To ask about time, hē is preceded by \textit{{\ꞌ}aŋa-}\is{anza- ‘recent past’@{\ꞌ}aŋa- ‘recent past’} (past) or a (future)\is{a- ‘future’}. \textit{{\ꞌ}Aŋahē} is written as one word; a hē is written as two words and is homophonic to a hē ‘by what place’ (see \REF{ex:10.57} above). The particles \textit{{\ꞌ}aŋa-} and a also occur with other roots (\sectref{sec:3.6.4}). As \REF{ex:10.64} shows, \textit{{\ꞌ}aŋahe} is preceded by locative prepositions.
Content 1: \gll ¿A hē nei rā i ŋaro ai? | \gls ~by CQ PROX INTENS PFV disappear PVP | \glt ‘In what direction did (the fish) disappear?’
Content 2: \gll ¿Mai \ꞌaŋahē \ꞌā a Rapa Nui i topa rō ai ki te tire? | \gls ~from when.PAST IDENT PROP Rapa Nui PFV happen EMPH PVP to ART Chile | \glt ‘From when did Rapa Nui go over to the Chileans?’

Knowledge Point: \subparagraph{Adjectival use} Finally, hē is used as an adjective ‘which’. As the examples below show, the questioned noun is preceded by the appropriate preposition marking its semantic role, but does not have a determiner. For example, the questioned NP in \REF{ex:10.65} is \textit{o hua{\ꞌ}ai hē}, not *\textit{o te hua{\ꞌ}ai hē}, even though the preposition o must normally be followed by a determiner (\sectref{sec:5.3.2.1}).
Content 1: \gll ¿O hua\ꞌai \textbf{hē} te rū\ꞌau era \ꞌai? | \gls ~~of family CQ ART old_woman DIST DEIC | \glt ‘From which family is that woman over there?’

Knowledge Point: There is no sharp difference in meaning between hē and aha used as adjective (see (\ref{ex:10.52}–\ref{ex:10.53}) above), except that the latter only occurs with time nouns, while hē occurs with any type of noun. Possibly hē implies a choice from a closed range, though \REF{ex:10.66} above appears to be a counterexample.
Content 1: \gll ¿Hora aha te manurere ka tu\ꞌu mai? | \gls ~~time what ART airplane CNTG arrive hither | \glt ‘What time does the plane arrive?’
Content 2: \gll ¿Mahana aha a koe ka oho ki Santiago? | \gls ~day what PROP 2SG CNTG go to Santiago | \glt ‘What day are you going to Santiago?’
Content 3: \gll —¿Ko poki \textbf{hē} rā poki hiko era i ta\ꞌa me\ꞌe? —Poki tane. | \gls ~~~~PROM child CQ DIST child snatch DIST ACC POSS.2SG.A thing ~~~child male | \glt ‘—Which child [was the child who] snatched your things? —A boy.’

Knowledge Point: Hia ‘how much, how many’ ({\textless} \is{Proto-Polynesian}PPN *fiha, with reflexes throughout Polynesia) is a numeral: it is always preceded by one of the numeral particles e, ka and hoko (\sectref{sec:4.3.2}). Hia may occur in a noun phrase as in (\ref{ex:10.67}–\ref{ex:10.68}), or as a separate constituent as in (\ref{ex:10.69}–\ref{ex:10.70}). In either case, it is placed at the start of the sentence.
Content 1: \gll ¿E hia māmari o roto te hakapupa? | \gls ~NUM how_many egg of inside ART nest | \glt ‘How many eggs are there inside the nest?’
Content 2: \gll ¿Ka hia matahiti ō\ꞌou, e pāpātio ē? | \gls ~CNTG how_many year POSS.2SG.O VOC uncle VOC | \glt ‘How old are you (lit. how many years are yours), uncle?’
Content 3: \gll ¿E hia tō\ꞌoku tārahu mō\ꞌou? | \gls ~NUM how_much POSS.1SG.O debt BEN.2SG.O | \glt ‘How much do I owe you (lit. how much [is] my debt for you)?’
Content 4: \gll ¿Hoko hia kōrua i oho ai? | \gls ~NUM.PERS how_many 2PL PVP go PVP | \glt ‘(With) how many did you go?’

Knowledge Point: \subparagraph{Polar questions} Dependent polar questions\is{Question!polar} are optionally introduced by hoki as in \REF{ex:10.72}. In \REF{ex:10.71}, hoki is not used, but here the question has a tag \textit{{\ꞌ}o {\ꞌ}ina}.
Content 1: \gll He kī ki te \ꞌauario o tū kona era \ob\textbf{hoki} e puē rō mo tari rō \ꞌai i tō\ꞌona me\ꞌe\,\cb. | \gls NTR say to ART guard of DEM place DIST {\db}PQ IPFV can EMPH for carry EMPH SUBS ACC POSS.3SG.O thing | \glt ‘She asked the guard of the place if he could carry her stuff.’
Content 2: \gll Kai \ꞌite mai au \obe take\ꞌa haka\ꞌou rō mai koe \ꞌo \ꞌina\,\cb. | \gls NEG.PFV know hither 1SG {\db}IPFV see again EMPH hither 2SG or NEG | \glt ‘I don’t know if you will see me again or not.’

Knowledge Point: This construction is similar in function to \textit{{\ꞌ}ai te} preceding an adjective (\sectref{sec:10.4.3} below); in fact, in \REF{ex:10.79} above the two constructions are used side by side. The choice between the two is lexically determined: while ka is only used with adjectives denoting a positive evaluation, \textit{{\ꞌ}ai te} is used with adjectives of size.
Content 1: \gll \ꞌAi te nuinui o te pū\ꞌoko ko tetu, ¡\textbf{ka} \textbf{ma\ꞌitaki} te pū\ꞌoko! | \gls there ART big:RED of ART head PROM enormous CNTG handsome ART head | \glt ‘The skull was this big, it was enormous, and how beautiful it was!’

Knowledge Point: In modern Rapa Nui, \is{ko (prominence marker)!in exclamations}ko te X is used in exclamations to convey a strong emotion about something.\footnote{\label{fn:491}\citet[149]{Moyse-Faurie2011} points out, that predicate (i.e. ko{}-marked) noun phrases in Polynesian languages often have an exclamative\is{Exclamative} function.} This usage does not occur in older texts. Sometimes it involves a noun as in \REF{ex:10.80}, but more commonly, exclamative\is{Exclamative} ko te is followed by an adjective as in \REF{ex:10.81}. The speaker expresses his or her emotion about the quality expressed, implying that the quality is true to a high degree: ‘How beautiful!’.
Content 1: \gll ¡Ko te manu hope\ꞌa o te tau! | \gls ~PROM ART animal last of ART pretty | \glt ‘What an extremely pretty animal!’
Content 2: \gll ¡Ko te tau! | \gls ~PROM ART pretty | \glt ‘How beautiful!’

Knowledge Point: \textit{{\ꞌ}Ina} is neutral with respect to aspect; the verb is always marked with the neutral aspectual he\is{he (aspect marker)}. It occurs in narrative contexts and habitual\is{Aspect!habitual} clauses, and it is used both for actions and states. However, it is used mostly in imperfective contexts; negations of one-time events tend to be expressed with other negators\is{Negation}, though \REF{ex:10.92} shows that this is not a strict rule.
Content 1: \gll He ha\ꞌamata he riri, \ꞌe \textbf{\ꞌina} he hakaroŋo ki tū vānaŋa era o tū hoa era ō\ꞌona. | \gls NTR begin NTR angry and NEG NTR listen to DEM word DIST of DEM friend DIST POSS.3SG.O | \glt ‘He began to get angry, and did not listen to the words of his friend.’

Knowledge Point: For the sake of comparison: the unmarked positive counterpart of \REF{ex:10.88} would be:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{\ꞌIna} a Heru he u\ꞌi rō mai hai mata. | \gls NEG PROP Heru NTR watch EMPH hither INS eye | \glt ‘Heru did not watch (her) with his eyes.’

Knowledge Point: In (\ref{ex:10.88}–\ref{ex:10.90}) above, the subject is a proper noun or pronoun. When the subject is a common noun and preverbal, it is usually not preceded by the article te, but by the predicate marker he\is{he (nominal predicate marker)}. This happens despite the fact that it refers to a definite entity, while he normally marks nonreferential noun phrases (\sectref{sec:5.3.4.1}).
Content 1: \gll \textbf{\ꞌIna} a Heru he u\ꞌi rō mai hai mata. | \gls NEG PROP Heru NTR watch EMPH hither INS eye | \glt ‘Heru did not watch (her) with his eyes.’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{\ꞌIna} mau \ꞌā koe he haŋa mai ki a au. | \gls NEG really IDENT 2SG NTR love hither to PROP 1SG | \glt ‘You really don’t love me.’

Knowledge Point: In (\ref{ex:10.94}–\ref{ex:10.96}) above, the construction \textit{{\ꞌ}ina he N VP} is a verbal clause in which he N is the preverbal subject. However, the same sequence of elements may also be an existential clause\is{Clause!existential}, in which the verb phrase is part of a relative clause\is{Clause!relative} (see (\ref{ex:10.107}–\ref{ex:10.109}) below on the negation of existential clauses\is{Clause!existential}).
Content 1: \gll \ꞌIna \textbf{he} \textbf{rū\ꞌau} \textbf{nei} he turu mai ki Haŋa Roa. | \gls NEG PRED old_woman PROX NTR go_down hither to Hanga Roa | \glt ‘This old women did not go down to Hanga Roa.’
Content 2: \gll ¿\ꞌIna \ꞌō \textbf{he} \textbf{mata} o Hotu \ꞌIti he taŋitaŋi ki te Tūpāhotu? | \gls ~~NEG really PRED tribe of Hotu Iti PRED cry:RED to ART Tupahotu | \glt ‘The tribe of Hotu Iti doesn’t mourn for the Tupahotu, does it?’
Content 3: \gll Matahiti nei \textbf{\ꞌina} he taŋata mo hāpī i te ŋā aŋa nei. | \gls year PROX NEG PRED person for teach ACC ART PL work PROX | \glt ‘This year there is no one (lit. there is no man) to teach these matters.’
Content 4: \gll \ꞌ\textbf{Ina} pa\ꞌi o māua kona mo noho. | \gls NEG in_fact of 1DU.EXCL place for stay | \glt ‘For we do not have a place to live.’

Knowledge Point: Constructions like (\ref{ex:10.98}–\ref{ex:10.99}) are quite distinct from (\ref{ex:10.94}–\ref{ex:10.96}) above. Firstly, the noun phrase does not refer to a specific entity, but predicates the existence of the category as a whole: ‘there is not...’ In the second place, the verb is marked in ways typical of relative clauses\is{Clause!relative}. While the verb in (\ref{ex:10.94}–\ref{ex:10.96}) has the neutral marker he, verbs in relative clauses\is{Clause!relative} are typically marked with the aspectuals i or e or with zero marking, but not by he (\sectref{sec:11.4.3}; \sectref{sec:11.4.5}).\footnote{\label{fn:492}That these two constructions are distinct is confirmed by the fact that i, e and zero marking never occur after \textit{{\ꞌ}ina} + proper noun or pronoun; they are limited to constructions with a common noun, which are open to an existential analysis.}
Content 1: \gll \ꞌIna he tētahi kona o te hakari [i \ꞌati]. | \gls NEG PRED other place of ART body ~PFV problem | \glt ‘(There is) no other part of the body (which) is in trouble.’
Content 2: \gll \ꞌIna he hua\ꞌai rahi [vānaŋa ki te ŋā poki i te re\ꞌo henua]. | \gls NEG PRED family many ~speak to ART PL child ACC ART voice land | \glt ‘(There are) not many families (who) speak the language of the island to the children.’
Content 3: \gll \ꞌIna \textbf{he} \textbf{rū\ꞌau} \textbf{nei} he turu mai ki Haŋa Roa. | \gls NEG PRED old_woman PROX NTR go_down hither to Hanga Roa | \glt ‘This old women did not go down to Hanga Roa.’
Content 4: \gll ¿\ꞌIna \ꞌō \textbf{he} \textbf{mata} o Hotu \ꞌIti he taŋitaŋi ki te Tūpāhotu? | \gls ~~NEG really PRED tribe of Hotu Iti PRED cry:RED to ART Tupahotu | \glt ‘The tribe of Hotu Iti doesn’t mourn for the Tupahotu, does it?’
Content 5: \gll \ꞌIna \textbf{he} \textbf{rū\ꞌau} \textbf{nei} he turu mai ki Haŋa Roa. | \gls NEG PRED old_woman PROX NTR go_down hither to Hanga Roa | \glt ‘This old women did not go down to Hanga Roa.’
Content 6: \gll ¿\ꞌIna \ꞌō \textbf{he} \textbf{mata} o Hotu \ꞌIti he taŋitaŋi ki te Tūpāhotu? | \gls ~~NEG really PRED tribe of Hotu Iti PRED cry:RED to ART Tupahotu | \glt ‘The tribe of Hotu Iti doesn’t mourn for the Tupahotu, does it?’

Knowledge Point: A third difference between verbal \textit{{\ꞌ}ina} clauses and existential constructions is, that in the latter the noun phrase after \textit{{\ꞌ}ina} is not always the S/A argument of the verb. This is illustrated in (\ref{ex:10.100}–\ref{ex:10.101}), where the noun phrase following \textit{{\ꞌ}ina} is the Patient. As \REF{ex:10.101} shows, the Agent may be expressed as a possessive, a construction common in relative clauses\is{Clause!possessive-relative} (\sectref{sec:11.4.4}).
Content 1: \gll \ꞌIna he me\ꞌe i rovā o tū pō era. | \gls NEG PRED thing PFV obtain of ART night DIST | \glt ‘They did not catch anything (lit. there was no thing obtained) that night.’
Content 2: \gll ¿\ꞌIna \ꞌō he \ꞌa\ꞌamu \ꞌā\ꞌau i ma\ꞌu mai mai Haŋa Roa? | \gls ~NEG really PRED story POSS.2SG.A PFV carry hither from Hanga Roa | \glt ‘Haven’t you brought any news (lit. are there no stories you brought) from Hanga Roa?’
Content 3: \gll ¿\ꞌIna \ꞌō he \ꞌa\ꞌamu \ꞌā\ꞌau i ma\ꞌu mai mai Haŋa Roa? | \gls ~NEG really PRED story POSS.2SG.A PFV carry hither from Hanga Roa | \glt ‘Haven’t you brought any news (lit. are there no stories you brought) from Hanga Roa?’

Knowledge Point: Constructions as in (\ref{ex:10.98}–\ref{ex:10.101}) are relatively unusual. More commonly, the noun phrase in negative existential constructions is preceded by the numeral e tahi ‘one’. \textit{{\ꞌ}Ina e tahi N} has become the usual way to express ‘not one, no one, nobody’:
Content 1: \gll \ꞌIna he tētahi kona o te hakari [i \ꞌati]. | \gls NEG PRED other place of ART body ~PFV problem | \glt ‘(There is) no other part of the body (which) is in trouble.’
Content 2: \gll ¿\ꞌIna \ꞌō he \ꞌa\ꞌamu \ꞌā\ꞌau i ma\ꞌu mai mai Haŋa Roa? | \gls ~NEG really PRED story POSS.2SG.A PFV carry hither from Hanga Roa | \glt ‘Haven’t you brought any news (lit. are there no stories you brought) from Hanga Roa?’

Knowledge Point: \textsc{Existential} clauses\is{Clause!existential} (\sectref{sec:9.3}) are negated by placing \textit{{\ꞌ}ina} in front of the nominal predicate as in \REF{ex:10.107}. The same is true for subtypes of existential clauses: existential-locative clauses as in \REF{ex:10.108}, possessive clauses as in \REF{ex:10.109}.
Content 1: \gll Matahiti nei \textbf{\ꞌina} he taŋata mo hāpī i te ŋā aŋa nei. | \gls year PROX NEG PRED person for teach ACC ART PL work PROX | \glt ‘This year there is no one (lit. there is no man) to teach these matters.’
Content 2: \gll He tike\ꞌa mātou e tahi kāiŋa \ꞌiti\ꞌiti, \textbf{\ꞌina} he taŋata o ruŋa. | \gls NTR see 1PL.EXCL NUM one homeland small:RED NEG PRED person of above | \glt ‘We saw a small island, there was nobody there.’
Content 3: \gll \ꞌ\textbf{Ina} pa\ꞌi o māua kona mo noho. | \gls NEG in_fact of 1DU.EXCL place for stay | \glt ‘For we do not have a place to live.’

Knowledge Point: \textsc{Locative} clauses (\sectref{sec:9.4.1}) can be negated with \textit{{\ꞌ}ina} in front of the subject. As in verbal clauses, the subject has the predicate marker he\is{he (nominal predicate marker)}, even when it has definite reference\is{Referentiality} (see (\ref{ex:10.94}–\ref{ex:10.96}) above).
Content 1: \gll \ꞌIna \textbf{he} \textbf{rū\ꞌau} \textbf{nei} he turu mai ki Haŋa Roa. | \gls NEG PRED old_woman PROX NTR go_down hither to Hanga Roa | \glt ‘This old women did not go down to Hanga Roa.’
Content 2: \gll ¿\ꞌIna \ꞌō \textbf{he} \textbf{mata} o Hotu \ꞌIti he taŋitaŋi ki te Tūpāhotu? | \gls ~~NEG really PRED tribe of Hotu Iti PRED cry:RED to ART Tupahotu | \glt ‘The tribe of Hotu Iti doesn’t mourn for the Tupahotu, does it?’

Knowledge Point: Alternatively, the locative phrase is negated by the constituent negator \textit{ta{\ꞌ}e} (see \REF{ex:10.143} on p.~\pageref{ex:10.143})\is{tae (negator)@ta{\ꞌ}e (negator)}.
Content 1: \gll Tō\ꞌoku hare \textbf{ta\ꞌe} a te ara ko Tu\ꞌu Kōihu. | \gls POSS.1SG.O house CONNEG by ART road PROM Tu’u Koihu | \glt ‘My house is not by the road Tu’u Koihu.’

Knowledge Point: Another possible indication for the verbal character of \textit{{\ꞌ}ina} is, that it can be followed by a wide range of verb phrase particles: certain adverbs (mau ‘really’, \textit{\mbox{tako{\ꞌ}a}} ‘also’), the emphatic marker rō, the directional\is{Directional} atu, postverbal demonstratives\is{Demonstrative!postverbal} and the identity marker \textit{{\ꞌ}ā}. This is illustrated in \REF{ex:10.90} above and in the following example:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{\ꞌIna} mau \ꞌā koe he haŋa mai ki a au. | \gls NEG really IDENT 2SG NTR love hither to PROP 1SG | \glt ‘You really don’t love me.’

Knowledge Point: Kai is used to negate events in narrative as in (\ref{ex:10.115}–\ref{ex:10.116}), and any past\is{Past} events as in (\ref{ex:10.117}–\ref{ex:10.119}).\footnote{\label{fn:498}The latter point is illustrated somewhat more extensively, to show that kai does indeed negate past tense clauses, the positive counterpart of which would have perfective i. In this respect my analysis is different from \citet[79]{Englert1978}, who claims that i{}-clauses are negated by \textit{ta{\ꞌ}e} (an analysis followed by \citealt[158]{Chapin1978} and \citealt[157]{Stenson1981}). In fact, \textit{ta{\ꞌ}e} is not the default negator of i, but is used to negate certain constructions with i and e (\sectref{sec:10.5.6} below).} If these clauses were positive, the former would be marked with he, the latter with perfective i or – if the speaker wishes to emphasise their present relevance – perfect \textit{ko V {\ꞌ}ā}\is{ko V {\ꞌ}ā (perfect aspect)}.
Content 1: \gll He hoki mai ki \ꞌuta, \textbf{kai} iri ki te hakanonoŋa. | \gls NTR return hither to inland NEG.PFV ascend to ART fishing_zone | \glt ‘They returned inland, they did not go out to the hakanononga fishing zones.’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Kai} pāhono e Hotu i tū vānaŋa era \ꞌa Tahoŋa. | \gls NEG.PFV answer AG Hotu ACC DEM word DIST of.A Tahonga | \glt ‘Hotu did not reply to those words of Tahonga.’
Content 3: \gll ¿He aha rā ia \ꞌina ho\ꞌi koe \textbf{kai} kī mai? | \gls ~PRED what INTENS then NEG indeed 2SG NEG.PFV say hither | \glt ‘Why then didn’t you tell me?’
Content 4: \gll E nua, \textbf{kai} kī mai ho\ꞌi koe pē hē te tunu haŋa o te kai era | \gls VOC Mum NEG.PFV say hither indeed 2SG like CQ ART cook NMLZ of ART food DIST | \glt ‘Mum, you didn’t tell me how to cook that food.’

Knowledge Point: In \REF{ex:10.117}, \REF{ex:10.120} and \REF{ex:10.122}, kai co-occurs with the neutral negator \textit{{\ꞌ}ina}\is{ina (negator)@{\ꞌ}ina (negator)}. There is little or no semantic or pragmatic difference between clauses with and without \textit{{\ꞌ}ina}, though he examples with \textit{{\ꞌ}ina} may be slightly more emphatic than constructions with kai alone.
Content 1: \gll ¿He aha rā ia \ꞌina ho\ꞌi koe \textbf{kai} kī mai? | \gls ~PRED what INTENS then NEG indeed 2SG NEG.PFV say hither | \glt ‘Why then didn’t you tell me?’
Content 2: \gll \ꞌIna a au \textbf{kai} maruaki. | \gls NEG PROP 1SG NEG.PFV hungry | \glt ‘I am not hungry.’
Content 3: \gll \ꞌIna a au \textbf{kai} haŋa mo iri atu. | \gls NEG PROP 1SG NEG.PFV want for ascend hither | \glt ‘I don’t want to go up (to the hospital).’

Knowledge Point: Just like any verb phrase, a verb phrase marked with kai may contain various kinds of postverbal particles, such as directionals\is{Directional} (mai in \REF{ex:10.117} and \REF{ex:10.119} above). When the clause has perfect aspect\is{Aspect!perfect}, the continuity marker \textit{{\ꞌ}ā/{\ꞌ}ana}\is{a (postverbal)@{\ꞌ}ā (postverbal)} may be added. This marker is obligatory with the perfect marker ko and indicates continuity of a state (\sectref{sec:7.2.5.5}); in combination with kai it indicates that the negative state still continues, i.e. that a positive action has not yet taken place, or that a positive state has not yet been reached.
Content 1: \gll ¿He aha rā ia \ꞌina ho\ꞌi koe \textbf{kai} kī mai? | \gls ~PRED what INTENS then NEG indeed 2SG NEG.PFV say hither | \glt ‘Why then didn’t you tell me?’
Content 2: \gll E nua, \textbf{kai} kī mai ho\ꞌi koe pē hē te tunu haŋa o te kai era | \gls VOC Mum NEG.PFV say hither indeed 2SG like CQ ART cook NMLZ of ART food DIST | \glt ‘Mum, you didn’t tell me how to cook that food.’

Knowledge Point: (E) ko\is{e ko (negator)|(}\footnote{\label{fn:499}The origin of ko is unclear. Pollex (\citealt{GreenhillClark2011}) mentions a negative imperative\is{Imperative} form *kaua in Fijian and Polynesian, which could have assimilated {\textgreater} *kō {\textgreater} ko. The semantic correspondence is tempting, but the evidence for *kaua is not very strong; more common is \textit{{\ꞌ}aua}, which occurs throughout Polynesian and which could be at the root of Rapa Nui \textit{{\ꞌ}o} ‘lest’ (\sectref{sec:11.5.4}). Alternatively, ko could be a shortening of kore, which is the main negator in verbal clauses in Central-Eastern Polynesian languages \citep[100]{Clark1976}. This would explain the fact that e is a fixed part of the negation in most contexts: in \is{Central-Eastern Polynesian}CE languages, kore fused with preceding aspectuals (esp. ka and e). NB kore itself also occurs in Rapa Nui as a lexical negator (\sectref{sec:10.5.7}).} is the imperfective negator. Like kai, it replaces the aspectual in front of the verb. The first element e (tentatively glossed as imperfective\is{e (imperfective)}) is almost always included, except in the imperative\is{Imperative}. Like kai, e ko it can be reinforced with \textit{{\ꞌ}ina}, which triggers preverbal verb placement; compare \REF{ex:10.126} and \REF{ex:10.127} below.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{E} \textbf{ko} \ꞌavai e au e tahi taŋata i tā\ꞌaku poki. | \gls IPFV NEG.IPFV give AG 1SG NUM one person ACC POSS.1SG.A child | \glt ‘I won’t give my child to anybody.’
Content 2: \gll \ꞌIna a au \textbf{e} \textbf{ko} \ꞌavai atu ki a koe i a Puakiva. | \gls NEG PROP 1SG IPFV NEG.IPFV give away to PROP 2SG ACC PROP Puakiva | \glt ‘I won’t give Puakiva to you.’

Knowledge Point: Finally, e ko negates stative verbs\is{Verb!stative}. This includes auxiliaries like puē\is{pue ‘can’@puē ‘can’}, as in \REF{ex:10.132}.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{E} \textbf{ko} puē ho\ꞌi tāua mo hī \ꞌi te kona nei. | \gls IPFV NEG.IPFV can indeed 1DU.INCL for to_fish at ART place PROX | \glt ‘We cannot fish in this place.’

Knowledge Point: Negative commands are marked by the imperfective negator (e) ko, usually in combination with \textit{{\ꞌ}ina}. While e is obligatory in other uses of the imperfective negator, in imperatives\is{Imperative} it is often left out, as in \REF{ex:10.133} and \REF{ex:10.135} below. However, when \textit{{\ꞌ}ina} is not included, as in \REF{ex:10.136}, e is obligatory.
Content 1: \gll Ka mou, \textbf{\ꞌina} koe \textbf{ko} taŋi haka\ꞌou. | \gls IMP quiet NEG 2SG NEG.IPFV cry again | \glt ‘Be quiet, don’t cry anymore.’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{\ꞌIna} \textbf{ko} pōŋeha \textbf{ko} makenu rahi tako\ꞌa. | \gls NEG NEG.IPFV noise NEG.IPFV move much also | \glt ‘Don’t make noise or move a lot.’
Content 3: \gll \textbf{E} \textbf{ko} oho koe ki te rua hare. | \gls IPFV NEG.IPFV go 2SG to ART other house | \glt ‘Don’t go to another house.’

Knowledge Point: \is{Imperative}First and third person injunctions are negated in the same way. Notice that in \REF{ex:10.138} below, the subject remains in postverbal position.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{\ꞌIna} \textbf{ko} tu\ꞌu haka\ꞌou \ꞌi te hora era e tahi taŋata. | \gls NEG NEG.IPFV arrive again at ART time DIST NUM one person | \glt ‘(When he was in mourning), at that time nobody could go to his house anymore.’

Knowledge Point: \subparagraph{\ref{sec:10.5.6}.1} \textit{Ta{\ꞌ}e} negates noun phrases which are the \textsc{predicate} of a nonverbal clause. This may be a classifying clause with a he{}-marked predicate (\sectref{sec:9.2.1}) as in \REF{ex:10.139},\footnote{\label{fn:501}There is a difference between:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Ta\ꞌe} he mōrore te poki nei, \ꞌā\ꞌau mau te poki nei. | \gls CONNEG PRED bastard ART child PROX POSS.2SG.A really ART child PROX | \glt ‘This child is not a bastard, the child is your own.’

Knowledge Point: \textit{{\ꞌ}Ina he taŋata} \textup{‘There is no man’ (existential, \REF{ex:10.102} in \sectref{sec:10.5.1})}\z} or an identifying clause with a ko{}-marked predicate (\sectref{sec:9.2.2}) as in \REF{ex:10.140}.
Content 1: \gll I oti era te \ꞌā\ꞌati, \ꞌina e tahi kope i \ꞌite ko ai te me\ꞌe i rē. | \gls PFV finish DIST ART contest NEG NUM one person PFV know PROM who ART thing PFV won | \glt ‘When the contest was finished, no one (lit. not one person) knew who had won.’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Ta\ꞌe} ko Reŋa Roiti ta\ꞌa me\ꞌe ena. | \gls CONNEG PROM Renga Roiti POSS.2SG.A thing MED | \glt ‘That one (lit. ‘your thing’) is not Renga Roiti.’

Knowledge Point: \subparagraph{\ref{sec:10.5.6}.2} \textit{Ta{\ꞌ}e} negates \textsc{other phrases}: prepositional phrases serving as arguments in a verbal clause as in (\ref{ex:10.141}–\ref{ex:10.142}), prepositional predicates as in \REF{ex:10.143}, possessive predicates as in \REF{ex:10.144}:
Content 1: \gll ¡\textbf{Ta\ꞌe} ho\ꞌi ki a koe a au i vānaŋa atu ai! | \gls ~CONNEG indeed to PROP 2S PROP 1SG PFV talk away PVP | \glt ‘It wasn’t to you I was talking!’
Content 2: \gll ...mahana va\ꞌai era i te mauku, \textbf{ta\ꞌe} i te henua | \gls ~~~day give DIST ACC ART grass CONNEG ACC ART land | \glt ‘the day when (king Atamu Tekena) gave the vegetation (to the Chileans), (but) not the land’
Content 3: \gll Tō\ꞌoku hare \textbf{ta\ꞌe} a te ara ko Tu\ꞌu Kōihu. | \gls POSS.1SG.O house CONNEG by ART road PROM Tu’u Koihu | \glt ‘My house is not by the road Tu’u Koihu.’
Content 4: \gll Te hare nei, \textbf{ta\ꞌe} ō\ꞌoku. | \gls ART house PROX CONNEG POSS.1SG.O | \glt ‘This house is not mine.’

Knowledge Point: \subparagraph{\ref{sec:10.5.6}.4} \textit{Ta{\ꞌ}e} negates \textsc{subconstituents}, such as adjectives \REF{ex:10.147} and quantifiers\is{Quantifier} \REF{ex:10.148} in the noun phrase.
Content 1: \gll A Hiero poki \textbf{ta\ꞌe} porio ni \textbf{ta\ꞌe} pāpaku. | \gls PROP Hiero child CONNEG fat nor CONNEG thin | \glt ‘Hiero was neither a fat nor a skinny child.’
Content 2: \gll Hora nei \textbf{ta\ꞌe} ta\ꞌato\ꞌa taŋata \ꞌite o ruŋa. | \gls time PROX CONNEG all person know of above | \glt ‘Nowadays, not all people know about it.’

Knowledge Point: Subordinate clauses without subordinating marker are also negated by \textit{ta{\ꞌ}e}. In these cases, \textit{ta{\ꞌ}e} co-occurs with an aspect marker\is{Aspect marker}, usually i or e. As in the examples above, \textit{ta{\ꞌ}e} occurs between the marker and the verb. Below are examples of relative clauses\is{Clause!relative} (\ref{ex:10.151}–\ref{ex:10.152}) (the second without aspectual), a temporal clause\is{Clause!temporal} \REF{ex:10.153}, and the conjunction\is{Conjunction} \textit{{\ꞌ}āhani} \REF{ex:10.154}.
Content 1: \gll Te vānaŋa rapa nui ta\ꞌe he me\ꞌe \obe \textbf{ta\ꞌe} haŋa rō \ꞌā e au\,\cb. | \gls ART word Rapa Nui CONNEG PRED thing {\db}IPFV CONNEG like EMPH CONT AG 1SG | \glt ‘The Rapa Nui language is not something I don’t like.’
Content 2: \gll A Julio taŋata \ob\textbf{ta\ꞌe} \ꞌite i te haka tere i te vaka\,\cb. | \gls PROP Julio person {\db}CONNEG know ACC ART CAUS run ACC ART boat | \glt ‘Julio is a man who does not know how to navigate a boat.’
Content 3: \gll I \textbf{ta\ꞌe} kore era tu\ꞌu tokerau era he mana\ꞌu mo haka tītika i te vaka ki Tahiti. | \gls PFV CONNEG lack DIST POSS.2SG.O wind DIST NTR think for CAUS straight ACC ART boat to Tahiti | \glt ‘When the wind did not die down, they decided to steer the boat to Tahiti.’
Content 4: \gll \ꞌĀhani \ꞌō tō\ꞌoku nua era i \textbf{ta\ꞌe} mate, \ꞌī au \ꞌi muri i a ia \ꞌi te hora nei. | \gls if_only really POSS.1SG.O Mum DIST PFV CONNEG die IMM 1SG at near in PROP 3SG in ART time PROX | \glt ‘If my mother had not died, I would be near her at this time.’

Knowledge Point: However, in such cases, main clause negators\is{Negation} are also used. This is illustrated in \REF{ex:10.117} above and in the following example:
Content 1: \gll ¿He aha rā ia \ꞌina ho\ꞌi koe \textbf{kai} kī mai? | \gls ~PRED what INTENS then NEG indeed 2SG NEG.PFV say hither | \glt ‘Why then didn’t you tell me?’

Knowledge Point: \subparagraph{10.5.6.7.} Finally, \textit{ta{\ꞌ}e} is used in combination with the other negators\is{Negation} to express \textsc{double negation}; \textit{ta{\ꞌ}e} and the other negator cancel each other out, resulting in a strong affirmation. The other negator may be kai\is{kai (negator)} or e ko\is{e ko (negator)}; as \REF{ex:10.161} shows, it may be reinforced by \textit{{\ꞌ}ina}\is{ina (negator)@{\ꞌ}ina (negator)}.
Content 1: \gll ...\textbf{\ꞌina} \textbf{e} \textbf{ko} \textbf{ta\ꞌe} rava\ꞌa te ika. | \gls ~~~NEG IPFV NEG.IPFV CONNEG obtain ART fish | \glt ‘(If the mother does not eat the fish caught by her firstborn son,) he will not fail to catch fish.’

Knowledge Point: Besides, kore is used to negate nouns, indicating that the entity expressed by the noun does not exist in the given context; as a noun negator it immediately follows the noun in adjective position. When the noun is a modifier as in \REF{ex:10.164}, kore can be translated as ‘without N’; in other cases as in (\ref{ex:10.165}–\ref{ex:10.166}), it can be translated as ‘lack of N’:
Content 1: \gll Te ŋā poki \textbf{matu\ꞌa} \textbf{kore} era o koā Eugenio te hāpa\ꞌo. | \gls ART PL child parent lack DIST of COLL Eugenio ART care_for | \glt ‘Children without parents, Eugenio and the others took care of them.’
Content 2: \gll Te \ꞌati he \textbf{matariki} \textbf{kore} mo oro o rā hora. | \gls ART problem PRED file lack for grate of DIST time | \glt ‘The problem was the lack of files to sharpen (the fishhooks) at the time.’
Content 3: \gll Ko pakiroki \ꞌā te taŋata \ꞌi te \textbf{kai} \textbf{kore}. | \gls PRF thin CONT ART person at ART food lack | \glt ‘The people were skinny from lack of food.’

Knowledge Point: Hia may occur with any negator: kai as in \REF{ex:10.167} above, e ko \REF{ex:10.168} or \textit{ta{\ꞌ}e} \REF{ex:10.169}.
Content 1: \gll ¡Kai topa \textbf{hia} atu \ꞌō tā\ꞌaku vānaŋa koe i pāhono rō mai ai! | \gls ~NEG.PFV descend yet away really POSS.1SG.A word 2SG PFV answer EMPH hither PVP | \glt ‘I hadn’t finished speaking yet when you answered!’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{E} \textbf{ko} \textbf{\ꞌo\ꞌoa} \textbf{hia} te moa ka kī ena e koe e toru kī iŋa kai \ꞌite koe ko ai a au. | \gls IPFV NEG.IPFV crow yet ART chicken CNTG say MED AG 2SG NUM three say NMLZ NEG.PFV know 2SG PROM who PROP 1SG | \glt ‘Before the rooster crows, you will say three times that you don’t know who I am.’
Content 3: \gll He \ꞌa\ꞌamu, mata \textbf{ta\ꞌe} \textbf{\ꞌite} \textbf{hia} pē nei ē: he tahutahu. | \gls NTR tell while CONNEG know yet like PROX thus PRED witch | \glt ‘She told it, without knowing yet that (the other person) was a witch.’

Knowledge Point: As (\ref{ex:10.167}–\ref{ex:10.168}) show, hia is often used when an action or event is interrupted by another event. In these cases, the function of the negator + hia is similar to a temporal marker ‘before’.
Content 1: \gll ¡Kai topa \textbf{hia} atu \ꞌō tā\ꞌaku vānaŋa koe i pāhono rō mai ai! | \gls ~NEG.PFV descend yet away really POSS.1SG.A word 2SG PFV answer EMPH hither PVP | \glt ‘I hadn’t finished speaking yet when you answered!’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{E} \textbf{ko} \textbf{\ꞌo\ꞌoa} \textbf{hia} te moa ka kī ena e koe e toru kī iŋa kai \ꞌite koe ko ai a au. | \gls IPFV NEG.IPFV crow yet ART chicken CNTG say MED AG 2SG NUM three say NMLZ NEG.PFV know 2SG PROM who PROP 1SG | \glt ‘Before the rooster crows, you will say three times that you don’t know who I am.’
